column4: OK. If I drop to root from the  CD's boot menu how much control over the system do I actually have.  For instance, can I delete and create files and folders?
You can do anything from the LiveCD
Do I need to do anything special?  Like to delete files?
What specifically are you trying to do and why?
I tried "sudo -i" but that didn't work
What specifically are you trying to do and why?
I removed and purged gimp.  I want to remove the left over files.(125)
"sudo" didn't work, nor does"sudo -i"
In what way didn't it work?
Sorry..more specifically  "sudo -i" should give me full permissions on all folders.  However it let me remove some folders but not others. And seemingly no files.
What is the exact command you are running and what is the error that you get?
No command per-se. I used "sudo -i" and made the password, expecting to select all the files and folders and delete them all at once.
made the password?
when I do "sudo -i" then I use "sudo password root" and enter a password
Why did you do that?

OK I read a tut, It said type "sudo -i" and that would temporarily be like logging in as root. It also said the I had to enable it by typing "sudo passwd root". Using search feature I found all the left over files.  I want to select them all, and delete them all at once. To do this I need to have full permissions on all the files and folders, and the tut said that "sudo -i" etc. would do it
You don't need to enable anything to use sudo -i, and you don't want to run "sudo passwd root" unless you really know what you are doing
OK. I'll accept that, but why does it not give me full permissions?
Or am I missing something here?
What permissions does it not give you? What command are you running and what error are you getting ( after running sudo -i )?
No error. The tut said "sudo -i" would be temporarily like logging in as root, which you can't do.  And that it would give me full permission on all files and folders.
And what makes you think "sudo -i" didn't do exactly that?
